result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Wesley Mark Charles

records.addlTxt: 22R 011051  Bond posted at Sheriff's Dept on 10/27/2022.

Not to operate a motor vehicle without a valid driver's license. No contact with: TG. Defendant to avoid the victim's residence and/or any location temporarily occupied by the victim. The defendant avoid contacting the victim or causing any person other than a party's attorney or law enforcement officer to contact the victim. Contact includes: contact at victim's home, work, school, public places, in person, by phone, in writing, by electronic communication or device, or in any other manner.

1:03 PM Defendant Wesley Mark Charles appeared by video from the Ozaukee County Jail, in custody.  Attorney Rachel Marie Boaz appeared by video for Wesley Mark Charles as a friend of the court.  Prosecuting attorney Benjamin Lindsay in court for the State of Wisconsin. Defendant does not qualify for PD. Counsel waives reading. Court advises of charges/penalties and finds probable cause. State recommends $5,000 cash bail w/conditions. Statement by victim. Counsel recommends $1,000 cash bail. Court finds good cause to extend time limits for preliminary hearing.
Status hearing scheduled for November 28, 2022 at 08:15 am.
